attachments.title: Project Cambria: Translate your data with lenses
attachments.text: Changing schemas in distributed software is hard. Could adopting bidirectional lenses help?
attachments.fallback: Project Cambria: Translate your data with lenses

text: I'll keep an eye on the thread here -- I suspect this work will be of interest to the community.

elements.text: I'll keep an eye on the thread here -- I suspect this work will be of interest to the community.

text:
Rails migrations for data, I like

Would be interested to know why the term "lens" is more helpful than just a vanilla "transformation" or "migration"

> A _lens_ is a bidirectional transformation between a pair of connected data structures, capable of translating an edit on one structure into an appropriate edit on the other.
Maybe it's so momentous that a strict new term is the only thing that suffices

That aside, looks like great work

elements.text:
Rails migrations for data, I like

Would be interested to know why the term "lens" is more helpful than just a vanilla "transformation" or "migration"
is a bidirectional transformation between a pair of connected data structures, capable of translating an edit on one structure into an appropriate edit on the other.

Maybe it's so momentous that a strict new term is the only thing that suffices

That aside, looks like great work

text: Well, the term lens is inherited from the research we implemented and describes a particular *kind* of transformation.  I would generally consider a "migration" to be a one-time single-direction process, but that might be bias from my own experience.

elements.text: Well, the term lens is inherited from the research we implemented and describes a particular
of transformation.  I would generally consider a "migration" to be a one-time single-direction process, but that might be bias from my own experience.

text: Cheers - it's a very nice publication

elements.text: Cheers - it's a very nice publication

text: I think the connotation of "lens" is that the transformation can change one little thing of a whole graph of data while keeping the rest intact

elements.text: I think the connotation of "lens" is that the transformation can change one little thing of a whole graph of data while keeping the rest intact

text: I don't think "lens" necessary implies bidirectional (as with regular migrations). Migrations can be rolled back sometimes, though.

elements.text: I don't think "lens" necessary implies bidirectional (as with regular migrations). Migrations can be rolled back sometimes, though.

text:
I've been transforming json structures like this whilst integrating and syncing data between two of my products and face the all the issues you mention in "Augmenting Data"

I've found, as you mentioned, it's necessary to be able to lookup data, either via objects within the same payload, or making another request, in order to apply the transformation. And to be able to reverse the transformation, it's necessary to have stored information (mostly object ids) from the initial transformation.

Also, with each transfer I've found it necessary to augment the data with some assumed information on each transformation, and I'm not sure it's possible to reverse without some dataloss. I'm also not sure I can reverse the changes with a single "lens" as some transformations aren't reversible.

Not sure if that's useful, but regardless of whether it's possible to do with or without dataloss, I think this research is great and will be a big step forward to in integrating services. I look forward to seeing where this goes!

I've been transforming json structures like this whilst integrating and syncing data between two of my products and face the all the issues you mention in "Augmenting Data"

I've found, as you mentioned, it's necessary to be able to lookup data, either via objects within the same payload, or making another request, in order to apply the transformation. And to be able to reverse the transformation, it's necessary to have stored information (mostly object ids) from the initial transformation.

Also, with each transfer I've found it necessary to augment the data with some assumed information on each transformation, and I'm not sure it's possible to reverse without some dataloss. I'm also not sure I can reverse the changes with a single "lens" as some transformations aren't reversible.

Not sure if that's useful, but regardless of whether it's possible to do with or without dataloss, I think this research is great and will be a big step forward to in integrating services. I look forward to seeing where this goes!
